article.title: Interstellar communication. III. Optimal frequency to maximize data rate

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the fraction of photons that defy interstellar extinction (SE) as a function of wavelength. What causes the significant drop in photon transmission around the 1 Âµm and 0.5 nm wavelengths?
choices: Scattering by free electrons in the interstellar medium
Ionization of neutral hydrogen in the Lyman continuum

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays the optimal wavelength for communication as a function of distance. What is the primary factor limiting the optimal wavelength for "Earth 2017" technology (red line)?

This figure compares the beam angles of different focusing methods as a function of energy. Why do free electron lasers (FELs) require significantly higher energy than photon mirrors to achieve the same beam angle?
choices: FELs suffer from higher energy losses due to diffraction.
The wavelength of photons produced by FELs is inherently larger.
Focusing particles into a tight beam is fundamentally less efficient than focusing photons.
FELs require stronger magnetic fields to operate at higher energies.

multiple_choice_question.text: This equation describes the scaling relation for data rate (DR) in interstellar communication. According to this equation, how does the data rate change if both the transmitter and receiver aperture diameters (Dt and Dr) are doubled, while keeping other parameters constant?
choices: DR increases by a factor of 2.
DR increases by a factor of 4.
DR increases by a factor of 8.
DR increases by a factor of 16.
